body: These are dark days, indeed, for one of New York City's best known and much maligned residents, the pit bull. The dog has long been a fixture in the tabloids and local news for the inevitable attacks that result from their corrupted rearing. But perhaps underscoring how debased the beast has become is the latest outcry for its banishment, spawned
title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-18-04: ESSAY; The Dog in the Fight

body: After 45 minutes of deliberation yesterday, a Federal District Court jury convicted Benjamin Harris, a temporary office worker from Crown Heights, of seven counts of tax fraud and filing a false return. His tax return for 2001 claimed that he had earned $9 million as a lawyer for the Temporary Time Capital Corporation and was entitled to a refund
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Temp Worker's Tax Fraud

body: New York City ended the year with a few more homicides than in 2002 -- but with fewer than 600, a number seen by police and city officials as a benchmark of a less violent era. The last time a year's total dropped below that number was 1963. The final tally for 2003 was 596 homicides, up from 587 in 2002, according to official statistics released
title: Homicides Up Slightly In New York City in '03
